bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: Walt Whitman to Dr. John Johnston, 9–10 November 1891
bibl.orgName: Henry S. Saunders collection of Walt Whitman papers, 1887–1923, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.
bibl.note: Whitman wrote this letter on the back of a November 6, 1891, letter he received from the Canadian physician Richard Maurice Bucke.

body.p: Have just had my supper—mutton chop, potato, & some stew'd pears—& there are ten minutes light enough to write a bit, & finish & send it off to-morrow—You will see that Dr Bucke is well & strong & hard at hard work—his estimate of J W W[allace] is one we all confirm, & we all felt sorry to let him go—the weather is finer than ever—probably Indian summer though without the slight haze belonging—it w'd have been a splendid experience for W to have staid another week if only to get a knowledge of that—Y'r kind letter yest'd'y—

Nov: 10—Sitting here again—just eaten my breakfast, buckwheat cakes & coffee—quite a budget of letters &c: by mail this mn'g—some ridiculous enough—have a g't pressure for autographs (never answer them)—I kill two birds with one stone by sending letters f'm Dr B to me—he is in his prime, must feel so, writes three or four times a week always cheery—ah there comes the sun shining out f'm the warm cloudy weather—Aff: regards to you & J W W & Wild & all the dear friends—
